Chesser has robust subvariation and comment parsing. ‚ÄìChesser‚Äôs author
Subvariations are enclosed by parentheses and comments by curly braces. Comments may also be implied when they appear outside parentheses. Type this: {Implied comment (1...e5 {{actual comment}} 2.Nf3 {{...}})} To display: Implied comment (1...e5 {actual comment} 2.Nf3 {...}) Show literal, non-subvariation parens as a comment by enclosing them in curly braces. Type this: {{{(Parenthetically speaking...)}}} To display: {(Parenthetically speaking...)} Use doubled curly braces to show a single literal brace. Type this: {{{{or}}}} To display: {{or}}

A subvar may continue directly after the mainline move. {(2.Nc3 2.Nf6)} ‚û°Ô∏è (2.Nc3 2.Nf6) A subvar may start with the same move as the mainline. This ‚Äúroot dupe‚Äù won‚Äôt be displayed if there are following moves. {(1...e5 2.d4)} ‚û°Ô∏è (1...e5 d4) We also drop nested root dupes {(e.g. Nc6)}: {(2.Nf3 Nc6 (2...Nc6 3.Bc4))} ‚û°Ô∏è (2.Nf3 Nc6 (2...Nc6 3.Bc4)) Root dupes are left alone when there are no following moves: {(1...e5)} ‚û°Ô∏è (1...e5) Subvars may also start with mainline ‚Äúsibling‚Äù moves: {(1...d5 exd5)} ‚û°Ô∏è (1...d5 exd5) Nested subvars may also start with siblings: {(1...c5 2.Nf3 (2.Bc4?))} ‚û°Ô∏è (1...c5 2.Nf3 (2.Bc4?)) Simple alternate moves: Instead of using a nested subvariation, alternate moves can be specified by making them follow a comment. There can be more than one alternate, and an alternate line may include follow-up moves. (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3) (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3 {or} 2.d4) (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3 Nf6) When things go wrong: ‚ùå marks the spot where parsing failed due to incorrect or ambiguous notation. {(2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bf4)} ‚û°Ô∏è (2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bf4) The parser will attempt to interpret variations with missing or incorrect move numbers. The result may or may not resolve into a legal, navigable line. {(Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6)} ‚û°Ô∏è (Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6)

Best by test. ‚ÄìBobby Fischer
The King‚Äôs Pawn Opening is the most popular first move at all levels of the game. 1.e4 opens lines to develop the Queen and the King‚Äôs Bishop. It also fights for control of the center. 1.e4 directly controls d5 and f5. If White wants to develop some pieces, the most important square they control by playing 1.e4 is, in fact, the e4 square itself: as long as there‚Äôs a White pawn on e4, there can‚Äôt be a Black pawn on e4, which means White‚Äôs g1-knight can be developed to f3 without fear of getting kicked away by a pawn and losing a tempo. Black has several ways to respond. The main idea is to find a way to prevent White from achieving or maintaining a two-pawn center with both e4 and d4. They may try to:
  • Control the d4 square.
  • Attack White‚Äôs e4 pawn directly.
  • Prepare to establish their own pawn on d5.
  • Let White build a center but prepare to undermine it later.

1...e5 serves to challenge White‚Äôs plan of having the center squares to themselves. Of course, just like White‚Äôs e4 move, e5 opens up the diagonals for Black‚Äôs Bishop and Queen. While the position is still symmetrical there are few limits to where White can take the game next.

The most common move is (2.Nf3), continuing the fight for the center. A more aggressive player might also go for the King‚Äôs Gambit with (2.f4). Black can take the pawn, but the gambit might allow White a quick and dangerous tactical attack. The former world chess champion, Bobby Fischer gave several great demonstrations of that opening‚Äôs deadly potential.

Black will want to be familiar with 2.Qh5, where White dreams of checkmating Black with a quick Scholar‚Äôs Mate. (2.Qh5 Nc6 3.Bc4 {and White hopes for something like} 3...Bc5? {or} 3...Nf6? 4.Qxf7#)

Nf3 is the classic of all classics. The Knight on f3 fights for control of the center by attacking Black‚Äôs e5 pawn. It also supports a potential d2-d4 move.

It‚Äôs common to develop the knight before the bishop across a wide range of openings. This is because there is usually only one good square for the knight, while the bishop has several options. We can see this in Black‚Äôs most common response, Nc6. Black could also counterattack with (2...Nf6), known as the Russian Game or Petrov Defense.

Black develops the Knight to c6, defending Black‚Äôs e5 pawn while also fighting for control of d4.

White can now choose between several well-known openings. The Ruy Lopez (3.Bb5), Italian Game (3.Bc4), and Scotch Game (3.d4) are all solid openings that see regular play at all levels. With the Ruy Lopez, White seeks to chase the initiative and attacks the defender of Black‚Äôs e5 pawn. In the Italian Game, the Bishop on c4 targets Black‚Äôs f7 pawn, the weakest pawn in the starting position. The Scotch Game with 3.d4 often leads to more concrete variations, with the central pawns being exchanged right away.

With this aggressive pawn advance, White looks to open up the center. (3...exd4) is played almost every time. It releases the central tension and leads to a very open game, with a lot of space for both players. (3...Nxd4{, the Lolli variation, is playable. White can trade on d4,} (4.Nxd4 exd4 5.Qxd4{, taking advantage of the fact Black has traded their Knight to centralize their Queen, or play}) (4.Nxe5)), threatening Qxd4. A few tries have been made with (3...d6{, transposing into a Philidor Defense, but this affords White a range of good options:} 4.d5{, kicking the Knight and expanding in the center is the most straightforward, or} 4.Bb5), transposing into an Old Steinitz Spanish.
Essentially the only move. Black contests the center.
This dubious move is the most popular one at lower levels and is often employed by intermediate players as well. It allows the Queen to centralize on d4, where she‚Äôs not easily attacked.

Now White can go for long castling and often launch a kingside attack. ‚öîÔ∏è

Some players like pushing (5...c5 {, which is good for White after} 6.Qe3 {, } 6.Qd3){, etc. Black might also play} (5...Qf6{, trying to trade queens, but after} 6.Qc4 Qc6 7.Nc3) we are generally happy to allow the queen trade in return for a strong lead in development.
This tepid move is the most popular in online games. Perhaps Black has been burned before by (5...Nf6? 6.e5!).
(6.Nc3) and other moves are fine, too.

Now c-pawn pushers might find themselves losing their d-pawn:

(8...c5? 9.Qd2 O-O 10.Bxd6!)

moves.text:
Nf3 is the classic of all classics. The Knight on f3 fights for control of the center by attacking Black‚Äôs e5 pawn. It also supports a potential d2-d4 move.

It‚Äôs common to develop the knight before the bishop across a wide range of openings. This is because there is usually only one good square for the knight, while the bishop has several options. We can see this in Black‚Äôs most common response, Nc6. Black could also counterattack with (2...Nf6), known as the Russian Game or Petrov Defense.

Black develops the Knight to c6, defending Black‚Äôs e5 pawn while also fighting for control of d4.

White can now choose between several well-known openings. The Ruy Lopez (3.Bb5), Italian Game (3.Bc4), and Scotch Game (3.d4) are all solid openings that see regular play at all levels. With the Ruy Lopez, White seeks to chase the initiative and attacks the defender of Black‚Äôs e5 pawn. In the Italian Game, the Bishop on c4 targets Black‚Äôs f7 pawn, the weakest pawn in the starting position. The Scotch Game with 3.d4 often leads to more concrete variations, with the central pawns being exchanged right away.

White develops the bishop to a good square where it controls a valuable diagonal. From c4 the Bishop controls d5 and pressures Black‚Äôs f7-pawn, the most vulnerable pawn in Black‚Äôs position. Having developed both their kingside minor pieces quickly, White is ready to castle. White‚Äôs plans include a swift attack on f7 and building a strong center with c3 and d4.

There is no immediate threat to Black‚Äôs position so they have some flexibility in how to respond. It would be good to develop a piece, and there are several options, the top two being (3...Nf6), the Two Knights, or (3...Bc5), the Giuoco Piano, which reflects a choice of whether to keep or to release control of g5.

Black develops a Knight and attacks the e4-pawn, getting one step closer to castling. This move seems like the most obvious one Black can play in the Italian, but it also comes at a disadvantage of blocking the d8-h4 diagonal of the black queen.

White has several ways to proceed from this position: defend the e-pawn, usually with (4.d3), attack f7 with the aggressive (4.Ng5), or sacrifice the pawn for an open center and swift attack.

The Knight Attack! We need to know a few things to defend against this common move at lower levels. {Even elite players occasionally use it as a surprise weapon, if they are in the mood for an irrational position} This Romantic move is an attack on f7 with the bishop and knight, taking advantage of the fact that Black gave up control of g5 and cannot castle yet. However, it is unprincipled to attack before having finished development. Siegbert Tarrasch slammed the move as ‚Äúbungling,‚Äù reflecting the classical view that early attacks without development are suspect. White might be hoping for the ‚ÄúFried Liver‚Äù attack: (4...d5 5.exd5 Nxd5 6.Nxf7! Kxf7 7.Qf3 Ke6) And while an engine might be able to defend this, it‚Äôs not a position most humans will enjoy playing. Fearful beginners sometimes play 3...h6 {to prevent this nasty incursion, but it passively loses a tempo to} 4.d4!, and while not losing outright, it starts us off on our back foot. It‚Äôs better‚Äîand more fun‚Äîto learn the lines so that we can happily engage with this aggression. There is only one response:
Black sacrifices a pawn in order to develop quickly and block White‚Äôs bishop‚Äôs attack on f7.
An automatic move as other moves lose material. Black has a selection of interesting moves leading to diverse tactical positions.
A knight on the rim is Black‚Äôs best move. It attacks the Bishop and gets out of the way of the pawn‚Äôs attack.

This is the main line of the Two Knights Defense. Black has sacrificed a pawn but gained a lead in development and improved central control. Now there are four moves to know. All are played frequently, contributing to the fun of... The Knight Attack! (8.Be2) is the old main line. White retreats the bishop to a square where it doesn‚Äôt block any of white‚Äôs pawns, but on the other hand, the white Knight on g5 is vulnerable to being chased all around the board. (8.Bd3 {is the modern main line. White blocks the d-pawn, but in return, gains the e4 square available for the knight to retreat, therefore this discourages} 8...h6 {because of} 9.Ne4!) in which White would gain an advantage. (8.Ba4? {looks to be natural, but is in fact a blunder because of} 8...h6 9.Nf3 e4!{, in which white‚Äôs Knight either has to go back to} 10.Ng1{, or move to} 10.Ne5{, in which case} 10...Qd4) wins material. Instead of moving the bishop, White might pin the c-pawn: (8.Qf3 {pins the c6 pawn to the rook on a8, and also attacks the c6 pawn for the second time. Black can play} 8...cxb5{, sacrificing the exchange for a massive lead in development, but more often continues with} 8...Be7 {or} 8...Rb8). If sacrificing one pawn isn‚Äôt enough for you, consider this line recommended by Jan Gustafsson in his Chessable 1.e4 e5 course: (8.Qf3 h6 9.Ne4 cxb5 10.Nxf6 gxf6 11.Qxa8 Qd7 {Now we‚Äôre down two pawns and the exchange, but Black is winning 57% to 38% in nearly 8,000 games on lichess, 17 Jan 2026. White‚Äôs Queen might find herself in trouble:} (12. Nc3 Nc6 13.d3 Ke7 14.Be3 Bb7) {And there are other wild rides:} (12.Qf3 Bb7 13.Qxf6 Rg8 14.Qxe5+ Be7 15.Rg1 Nc6 16.Qxb5 Rg5)) Where Black is down a lot of material but the engine gives an evaluation of nearly -4. üí™

moves.text: The main idea of the Alekhine is to invite White to advance and overextend their pawns, which Black hopes to undermine later. The opening is named after Alexander Alekhine, who introduced it in 1921. {(The theory and mainlines were developed much later.)} While it is not played very often at the very top level, the Alekhine is not unsound. White‚Äôs most popular continuation is (2.e5), dreaming of building a large center with d4, later c4, and sometimes even f4. Black‚Äôs plan is to provoke this expansion and then attack and dismantle White‚Äôs pawn center. If White doesn‚Äôt want to follow the main line, they may simply defend the pawn with (2.Nc3), perhaps transposing to the Vienna Game. (2.Bc4 {is the sharp Krejcik Variation. It looks like a gambit, but if Black plays} 2...Nxe4 {White can regain the pawn and prevent Black from castling with} 3.Bxf7+ Kxf7 4.Qh5+)
Black‚Äôs knight is under attack. The most popular, and probably best, move is (2...Nd5), although rarely (2...Ne4) and even (2...Ng8) have been played, with poorer results.

White‚Äôs pawn is now weak and needs reinforcement. The most intuitive move is (3.d4), but White can also keep on attacking the knight and play (3.c4) first.

(3.Nc3 {is an option for White to avoid the sharpest lines of the Alekhine. In compensation for doubled pawns, White can accelerate their development after} 3...Nxc3 4.dxc3{, or strengthen their center and grab extra space with} 4.bxc3{.})
With his knight finally safe, Black can start to put pressure on White‚Äôs pawn center. The most aggressive move in this position is (3...d6) or (3...e6).
The O‚ÄôSullivan Gambit! This is a poor but tricky move that scores well in online games. Eric Rosen has shared a video and lichess study about it, shown in this variation‚Äôs sources.
Black hopes for (5.dxc5?? Qa5+), winning the bishop.
Eric covers a possible counter trap for White: (5.Bc4 cxd4 6.Bxd5 Qa5+ 7.Nc3 dxc3 8.b4! {Allowing White to take on a8. Not:} 8.Bxa8 cxb2+), which is a disaster.

Qxd4 is the most common continuation, and it‚Äôs not a bad move. Beware of the following trap, however:

(6.Qxd4 Nb4 7.Na3? {This develops the knight while protecting c2, but it gives up all of White‚Äôs considerable advantage. It is nevertheless the most popular move, and allows Black to set a trap with} 7...Qa5{. This swings the evaluation back to White, but tempts a natural response that neglects the weak c2 square:} 8.Bd2 Qxa3! 9.Qe4 Qxb2 10.Rb1 Qxe5 11.Qxe5 Nd3+ 12.Ke2 Nxe5)
Engine likes 6...e6, (6...a6{, and} 6...Bb7), among other things. (6...a6 {is played the most and scores the best for White.} 7.cxd5 Qa5+ 8.Qd2)

mainline: 1.e4 Nf6 2.e5 Nd5 3.d4 b5 4.Bxb5 c5 5.c4 cxd4 6.Nf3 e6 7.Qxd4

moves.text: Let‚Äôs look at one of my favorite lines in an opening that‚Äôs near and dear to me.

A major practical benefit of the Scandinavian is that 2.exd5 is White‚Äôs *only* theoretically critical try for an advantage. Attempts to advance or defend the e-pawn with (2.e5) or (2.Nc3) might even leave White worse! As such, it often feels like White is forced to fight on Black‚Äôs territory with 2.exd5.
Achieving central clarity. Black has a gambit alternative in {2...Nf6}, but I‚Äôve usually preferred to recover the pawn straight away.

In roughly two-thirds of games White develops and attacks the queen with (3.Nc3{, whereupon I recommend tucking the queen on the edge of the board with} 3...Qa5{. (}3...Qd6 {and} 3...Qd8) {are also playable.) Developing the kingside knight is arguably more ambitious, though: White may be working up to a big center with d2-d4 and c2-c4.}
{White‚Äôs pawn-pushing plan is dangerous, and Black ought to respond actively! With 3...Bg4, Black pins the knight and hints at rapid queenside castling (...Nb8-c6 and ...0-0-0).}
Breaking the pin and addressing the strategic threat of 4...Bxf3.
Readying queenside castling. Note Black‚Äôs influence of the d4 square.
Despite Black‚Äôs no-nonsense development, White boldly occupies the center.
Not (5...Bxf3? 6.Bxf3 Qxd4??{, which loses the queen to a removal of the defender tactic,} 7.Bxc6+).
Following through! The possibility of c2-c4 is the point of delaying Nb1-c3.
An active post for the Black queen.
White appears to be doing well with their centralized minor pieces and compelling c+d pawn duo. This is a common position in the 3.Nf3 line, but here comes a surprise!
Tearing down White‚Äôs center - seemingly out of nowhere! Black is sacrificing a piece, but they will regain it with interest.
At first (9.Bg4 {appears crushing, but Black has the timely riposte} 9...Nc2+!{, intending} 10.Qxc2 Qxg4), with an extra pawn.
Exactly this check! The hasty (9...e5?? {or} 9...c5?? {would have lost the queen to the pin} 10.Bg4).
Instead, (10.Qe2?! {allows} 10...Qxe2+) followed by 11...Rxd4. Even worse is (10.Kf1?{, which runs into the fork} 10...Qxc4+).

Due to the d-file pin, Black will next regain the piece with 10...Rxd4 or 10...cxd4, with an extra pawn to boot. Even after seeing it dozens of times, I‚Äôm mesmerized by the sequence beginning with 7...Bxf3! 8.Bxf3 Nxd4!. It‚Äôs incredible that it all checks out for Black. Thanks to my friend/Chesser creator Scott Carpenter for allowing me to present my favorite Scandinavian line! If the Scandinavian Defense appeals to you, please check out my complete coverage on Chessiverse. Also, take advantage of our 600+ human-like bots!

mainline: 1.e4 d5 2.exd5 Qxd5 3.Nf3 Bg4 4.Be2 Nc6 5.d4 O-O-O 6.c4 Qf5 7.Be3 Bxf3 8.Bxf3 Nxd4 9.Bxd4 Qe6+ 10.Be2 c5

Variation View / Book Mode This page is usually reached by clicking on a variation link or pressing the View button. This is where you can fully explore an opening line. Each variation has three modes:
  • View {(Stacked books emoji)}
  • Edit {(Hammer & wrench emoji)}
  • Review: {(Memo emoji: paper with pencil)}
You can switch between modes at any time. {(Leaving a quiz in progress will cancel it, but you can resume your review session by returning to Review mode.)} Reviews are sometimes called ‚Äúquizzes,‚Äù since you‚Äôre testing yourself on an opening. Wherever the Review button appears, it always takes you to the current ‚ÄúNext Review Due‚Äù. {(Most likely not the variation you're looking at.)} It's meant to let you quickly start or resume a review session at any time. View UI Elements The interface is intentionally somewhat dense. Once you know the pieces, you can scan a lot of information at once ‚Äî just like a chessboard! What looks busy at first becomes readable with familiarity. {(We can hope.)} On mobile devices, some interface elements require scrolling to view. {(We're leaving more room for move text.)}
  • üìå Tutorial ‚Äî The variation title. The pushpin means it's marked as an ‚Äúintro‚Äù line and will appear at the top of the chapter list.
  • üå± ‚Äî The sprout means this variation is new / unstarted.
  • L0 ‚Äî The current spaced-repetition level. Higher levels mean longer review intervals {(up to 6 months)}.
  • S1 ‚Äî The starting move for quizzes / extra study.
  • N‚û§end of time ‚Äî Time to next review. ‚ÄúEnd of time‚Äù means no review is scheduled. Other examples: N‚û§15d {(15 days)}, N‚û§4h 26m {(4 hours, 26 minutes)}. If you schedule a review for a level 0 variation, spaced repetition begins at that time.
  • #7 ‚Äî The variation ID.
  • learn üìñ ‚Äî Take the quiz and start spaced repetition. Pass or fail, you move to level 1 and the variation enters the review cycle.
  • extra study ‚úèÔ∏è ‚Äî Once a variation is learned / in progress, you can quiz yourself without affecting progress. Pass or fail, nothing is recorded. Level and next review stay unchanged.
